title: Pay transparency is now law in Massachusetts. What does it mean for you?
author: Pattie Hunt Sinacole
bullets: Massachusetts' new pay transparency law requires employers with 25+ employees to disclose salary ranges in job postings.
The law applies to all compensation types, including commission, tip, or hourly roles, and prohibits employer retaliation.
Massachusetts employers with 100+ employees must submit annual wage data, effective since February 2025.

title: Salem woman who ran ‘creepy creations’ shop to plead guilty in Harvard morgue scandal
author: Abby Patkin
bullets: Katrina Maclean of Salem to plead guilty to transporting stolen goods in Harvard morgue scandal.
Maclean allegedly bought human remains from Harvard's Cedric Lodge, selling them at her Peabody shop.
Prosecutors recommended 12-month prison sentence and $250,000 fine for Maclean's plea deal.

title: Tell us: What’s the best New England town for a winter weekend getaway?
author: Kristi Palma
bullets: Boston.com seeks reader recommendations for New England winter weekend getaway towns.
Popular spots include Boston, Nantucket, Sandwich, Woodstock, Bar Harbor, Portsmouth, Littleton, and Mystic.
Submissions may be featured on Boston.com and can be sent via a form or email.

title: Boston ranks among best U.S. cities for Thanksgiving — and tops New England
author: Frances Klemm
bullets: Boston ranks 18th on WalletHub's list of top 100 U.S. cities for Thanksgiving.
Boston leads New England in Thanksgiving city rankings, credited to its highly-rated restaurant scene.
Volunteer rates and charitable activities contributed to Boston's high ranking in 'Giving Thanks' indices.

title: Five years after debuting ‘Java with Jimmy,’ host James Hills isn’t slowing down
author: Ross Cristantiello
bullets: James 'Jimmy' Hills started 'Java with Jimmy' as a Facebook livestream addressing COVID-19's impact on Boston's communities of color.
The show features interviews with political figures like Gov. Maura Healey and Rep. Ayanna Pressley, and community leaders.
Hills sees his show as a platform for community building and has aspirations for expanding into a dedicated platform or studio.

title: Roman Anthony earns a third place finish for AL Rookie of the Year
author: Aidan Buchanan
bullets: Roman Anthony finished third in the American League Rookie of the Year vote, behind Nick Kurtz and Jacob Wilson.
Anthony hit .292 with eight home runs and 32 RBIs in 71 games for the Boston Red Sox.
Despite finishing third, Anthony signed an eight-year, $130 million extension with the Red Sox in August.

title: Federal judge orders release of Fitchburg woman detained by ICE in viral video
author: Abby Patkin
bullets: Federal judge Stacey D. Neumann ordered the release of Juliana Milena Ojeda Montoya after her arrest by ICE in Fitchburg.
Judge Neumann ruled Ojeda Montoya's detention violated due process, setting briefs deadline on Laken Riley Act applicability.
Ojeda Montoya, arrested in August for assault, was involved in an ICE traffic stop that allegedly caused her husband a seizure.

title: How Mass. lawmakers are reacting to the deal that could end the government shutdown
author: Ross Cristantiello
bullets: Massachusetts lawmakers criticize the Senate-approved funding package, citing the lack of federal health care subsidies extension.
Rep. Seth Moulton pushes for leadership change within the Democratic Party, opposing the shutdown deal without health care concessions.
Massachusetts Representatives, including Ayanna Pressley and Jake Auchincloss, express strong opposition to the current funding agreement.

title: Boston firefighters battle 2-alarm blaze at multi-family home in Dorchester
author: Madison Lucchesi
bullets: Boston Fire Department extinguished a two-alarm fire at a multi-family home on Train St., Dorchester.
The fire, starting around 8:30 a.m., displaced two residents and caused $500,000 in damages.
One firefighter was hospitalized, and an investigation into the fire's cause is ongoing.

title: Here’s what Jon Stewart had to say about the Senate Democrats voting to end the shutdown
author: John Waller
bullets: Jon Stewart criticized Senate Democrats, calling their decision to end the shutdown a 'world class collapse.'
The Senate Democrats voted to approve legislation aimed at ending the federal government shutdown.
Boston.com deputy editor John Waller reported on the comments following the Senate's legislative action.
